title: Why Savoring Might Just Be Your Leadership Superpower
description: If you’re always sprinting toward what’s next, you’re missing what’s best.
author: Moshe Engelberg
excerpt: Savoring the present moment and small wins make you a stronger leader. Here's how to adopt the superpower of savoring into your leadership.
text: Remember the last time you really savored something? Maybe it was a velvety glass of pinot noir, a hug from your little one, or a quiet sunset during which time stood still. You paused, noticed, and let it land. You didn’t rush to the next activity. Instead, you simply enjoyed. Now, imagine bringing that same presence and pleasure to your leadership. Yes, leadership.  When savoring becomes a leadership superpower Savoring in leadership means lingering in the goodness—not bragging or clinging. It’s about genuinely being present and appreciative. It could mean taking in a moment of deep team connection after a tough win. Feeling the alignment when your values, your vision, and your team click; or appreciating a colleague’s growth that you helped shape. The opposite of savoring looks like plowing through the next item on the to-do list, downplaying successes, or brushing past meaningful moments because, well, there’s always more to do. This is where mindfulness meets meaning. Science-backed benefits worth savoring The Greater Good Science Center at UC Berkeley reports that savoring boosts happiness, resilience, and connection. In a leadership context, that means better decision-making, stronger relationships, and more presence—not just for others, but for yourself. Savoring isn’t passive pleasure. It’s active awareness. Leaders who practice savoring tend to radiate calm, make more values-aligned choices, and create ripple effects of positivity. They’re the ones who can handle the heat, and still taste the soup. Create a positive experience around a circumstance or situationEssentially, savoring means positively appreciating an experience. In other words, creating an experience of appreciation around something that you have already experienced.  However, if you’re like many people, you have lots of practice doing the opposite—that is, negatively analyzing an experience and diminishing it. For example, replaying a bad meeting, obsessing over a mistake, or letting one critical comment drown out 99 affirming ones. That, too, is “creating an experience,” but around pain, fear, and self-doubt. It’s called ruminating.  Savoring is the high-vibration twin of rumination. It’s not about fulfilling every desire. It’s about enjoying the moment, appreciating the unfolding, and soaking in the beauty of what is, not just what’s next.  Consider your experiences:  What recent leadership moment did you rush past that deserved savoring?  How often do you create experiences around the negative rather than the positive?  Where can you slow down to experience more joy, even amid busyness?  5 steps to savor your leadership journey  Make the conscious choice to savor. Throughout your day, ask yourself: Is there something here that I can appreciate right now? Then, appreciate it!  Build a pause between moments. After a meeting, a breakthrough, or even a challenge, take 30 seconds to breathe and notice how it feels. That pause is where savoring starts.  Share the good out loud. Amplify savoring by articulating what you appreciate to yourself and others. “That felt meaningful” or “I really enjoyed that exchange” goes a long way.  Celebrate without rushing to “what’s next.” Give yourself (and your team) time to acknowledge progress before chasing the next goal. It nourishes motivation far better than burnout ever could.  Don’t hyperfocus on the outcome, enjoy the experience. Let go of needing everything to turn out just right. Instead, relish the effort, intention, and whatever experience you manifested. That also gets the best results!  Savor the power of now Savoring doesn’t happen by accident. html:
Remember the last time you really savored something? Maybe it was a velvety glass of pinot noir, a hug from your little one, or a quiet sunset during which time stood still. You paused, noticed, and let it land. You didn’t rush to the next activity. Instead, you simply enjoyed. Now, imagine bringing that same presence and pleasure to your leadership. Yes, leadership.  

When savoring becomes a leadership superpower 

Savoring in leadership means lingering in the goodness—not bragging or clinging. It’s about genuinely being present and appreciative. It could mean taking in a moment of deep team connection after a tough win. Feeling the alignment when your values, your vision, and your team click; or appreciating a colleague’s growth that you helped shape. 

The opposite of savoring looks like plowing through the next item on the to-do list, downplaying successes, or brushing past meaningful moments because, well, there’s always more to do. This is where mindfulness meets meaning. 

Science-backed benefits worth savoring 

The Greater Good Science Center at UC Berkeley reports that savoring boosts happiness, resilience, and connection. In a leadership context, that means better decision-making, stronger relationships, and more presence—not just for others, but for yourself. 

Savoring isn’t passive pleasure. It’s active awareness. Leaders who practice savoring tend to radiate calm, make more values-aligned choices, and create ripple effects of positivity. They’re the ones who can handle the heat, and still taste the soup. 

Create a positive experience around a circumstance or situation

Essentially, savoring means positively appreciating an experience. In other words, creating an experience of appreciation around something that you have already experienced.  

However, if you’re like many people, you have lots of practice doing the opposite—that is, negatively analyzing an experience and diminishing it. For example, replaying a bad meeting, obsessing over a mistake, or letting one critical comment drown out 99 affirming ones. That, too, is “creating an experience,” but around pain, fear, and self-doubt. It’s called ruminating.  

Savoring is the high-vibration twin of rumination. It’s not about fulfilling every desire. It’s about enjoying the moment, appreciating the unfolding, and soaking in the beauty of what is, not just what’s next.  

Consider your experiences: 

  • What recent leadership moment did you rush past that deserved savoring? 
  • How often do you create experiences around the negative rather than the positive? 
  • Where can you slow down to experience more joy, even amid busyness? 

5 steps to savor your leadership journey 

  • Make the conscious choice to savor. Throughout your day, ask yourself: Is there something here that I can appreciate right now? Then, appreciate it! 
  • Build a pause between moments. After a meeting, a breakthrough, or even a challenge, take 30 seconds to breathe and notice how it feels. That pause is where savoring starts. 
  • Share the good out loud. Amplify savoring by articulating what you appreciate to yourself and others. “That felt meaningful” or “I really enjoyed that exchange” goes a long way. 
  • Celebrate without rushing to “what’s next.” Give yourself (and your team) time to acknowledge progress before chasing the next goal. It nourishes motivation far better than burnout ever could. 
  • Don’t hyperfocus on the outcome, enjoy the experience. Let go of needing everything to turn out just right. Instead, relish the effort, intention, and whatever experience you manifested. That also gets the best results! 

Savor the power of now 

Savoring doesn’t happen by accident. It’s a decision to notice, to pause, to allow in goodness without trying to make anything happen. If you’re always sprinting toward what’s next, you miss what’s best. Savoring is how leaders stretch time, deepen joy, and stay grounded in love.  

It’s a quiet rebellion against hurry and a bold invitation to presence. You don’t have to earn it—you just have to notice it. Savor this moment now.
